results: I was completely unaware of this Adam Sandler film until I stumbled upon it at Blockbuster. As a devoted fan of Adam Sandler, I decided to give it a chance and rented it. To be completely honest, I could only endure about 30 minutes of it. It was absolutely dreadful. Every effort should be made to prevent the public from getting their hands on this movie. Frankly, I sincerely wish this film becomes out of print soon, and I strongly desire it remains that way!

It was TERRIBLE. Do whatever it takes to keep this out of the hands of the public. I honestly hope this movie goes OOP soon, and I hope it STAYS THAT WAY!

results:
There are countless flaws in this terrible excuse for a film that it's difficult to even know where to start. This so-called horror movie is incredibly un-scary, even by American standards. The dialogue is cliché, the characters are one-dimensional, the writing is mediocre, and the nonexistent plot is neither coherent nor remotely interesting.

We are introduced to a series of predictable stereotypes: a balding loser guy (probably divorced, but the movie doesn't bother to clarify), a young hero who doesn't display any heroic qualities, a brave little kid with a disturbingly violent streak, and a black bad-ass woman with more brawn than brains. These characters engage in an ongoing battle with the tall, scary reaper man and his evil Ewoks.

To add to the absurdity, the film includes these wicked little metal orbs that fly around menacingly and perform impromptu brain surgeries on unsuspecting victims. Boo! One of these orbs is supposedly haunted by a benevolent ghost, although it's unclear if the ghost can be trusted. This ghost seems determined to help our brave protagonists rescue their kidnapped friend.

None of the characters are given any background or introduction. The movie begins with a recap of the previous film's ending, which does little to provide context. If you've seen the first two movies, great. Otherwise, you're left in the dark about who these people are, how they are connected, why they aren't in school or at work, or why their lives matter. Consequently, you simply don't care. The only mildly interesting aspect becomes the occasional splatter effects, but even those are far too few to keep you engaged.

The only potentially amusing part of the movie is the appearance of three raider punks, who are both stupid and evil. They pose a threat to our heroes but are quickly disposed of. They are then inexplicably buried, only to return as evil raider punk zombies. However, they are promptly killed off again within a minute.

The majority of the film seems to consist of Caspar the Friendly Ghost appearing and disappearing, driving around aimlessly, and the balding loser guy attempting to seduce the black bad-ass woman with pickup lines that would embarrass a mentally challenged teenager. This subplot goes nowhere, and not even gratuitous sex could have salvaged this train wreck of a movie (not that it ever happens).

The main antagonist, known as the Tall Man, fails to scare anyone above the age of three. Repeatedly
prompts:

First of all, it's a remarkably un-scary scary movie, even by Amercian standards. The dialogue is cliché, the characters are two-dimensional, the writing is ho-hum, and what little story there is is neither coherent nor remotely interesting.

We meet the following stereotypes in order: Balding Loser Guy (probably divorced, but who knows? This movie doesn't tell us) with a brave heart, the Young Hero (who doesn't do anything heroic at all), Brave Little Kid (with a homicidal streak a mile wide) and Black Bad-Ass Bitch (with more brawn than brains). These guys take up an ongoing fight with the Tall Scary Reaper Man and his evil Ewoks.

Oh, and the film is full of wicked little metal orbs whoosing around menacing people. Given a chance, they perform impromptu brain surgery on those who doen't have the mental acuity to duck when they come at them. Booh! Actually, one of them is haunted by a good ghost (but then again, it might be a deceitful spectre) who seems intent on helping our Brave Contagonists retrieve their young kidnapped friend.

There is no character background or even an introduction to any of the characters. It starts with some kind of recap of the ending of the previous movie, but this doesn't explain a lot. If you've seen the first two movies, fine. Otherwise you don't know who these people are, how they are related, why they aren't in school or at work, or why you should care whether they live or die. Consequently, you don't. The only point of interest becomes any splatter effects. And there aren't enough of those to keep you awake.

Of potenial interest/amusement are the three Raider Punks, as stupid as they are evil, who menace Our Heroes. But they don't get much screen time. They are offed almost immediately. Then they are buried (why anybody should take the time is beyond me), then they appear again as Evil Raider Punk Zombies. Only to be offed again, literally within a minute.

The rest of the movie mainly seems to consist of Caspar the Friendly Ghost appearing and disappearing, driving around looking for places, and Balding Loser trying to score som Bad Black Bitch Booty, using pickup lines that would embarrass a mentally retarded teenager. No dice there; not even some gratuitous sex could have saved this movie, so good thing there never is any.

The head baddie, called the Tall Man, doesn't manage to scare anyone older than 3 years; howling 'Booooy!' every five minutes isn't enough. Why he, with his amazing telekinetic powers and uncanny upper-body strength, doesn't simply squash our heroes like bugs isn't explained. Instead, he delegates the job to his inept retarded little minions, who never manage to kill anyone before being shot to hell.

Filmgoers who like masterpieces like 'Friday 13th part XXXXVIII: Jason goes to college' might find some entertainment. The rest of us, who have developed pubic hair, will be bored out of our skulls. Text:

results:
Ealing Studios, a film production company located in West London, claims to be the oldest film studio globally, boasting a rich history dating back to the 1930s. However, it was during the period between 1948 and 1955 that the studio truly shone, producing a series of comedic masterpieces, many of which starred the legendary Alec Guinness. Notable titles from this era include 'Whisky Galore! (1949),' 'Passport to Pimlico (1949),' 'Kind Hearts and Coronets (1949),' 'The Lavender Hill Mob (1951),' 'The Titfield Thunderbolt (1953)' and 'The Ladykillers (1955).' Among these beloved films, 'The Man in the White Suit' stands out, released in 1951 and featuring Alec Guinness in the lead role as Sidney Stratton, a brilliant inventor who creates a revolutionary fabric that attracts more enemies than friends.

Sidney Stratton, despite his immense scientific talent, finds himself impoverished and underappreciated. Due to his lack of qualifications, he is only able to secure menial jobs as a janitor or laborer in large textile factories. Secretly, he conducts his own experiments using the company's resources and funds. Even after being discovered and ejected numerous times, Sidney remains convinced that he is on the brink of a groundbreaking scientific discovery that will transform the textile industry. Encouraged by his daughter Daphne (portrayed by Joan Greenwood), textile mill owner Alan Birnley (played by Cecil Parker) takes a keen interest in Sidney's endeavors and agrees to provide financial support. After several failed attempts and a series of explosive mishaps, Sidney finally unveils his remarkable creation: an almost luminous white fabric that stays perpetually clean and never wears out.

However, Sidney's belief that his invention will make him a hero is swiftly shattered. The powerful figures in the textile industry, led by the frail Sir John Kierlaw (portrayed by Ernest Thesiger), band together to ensure that this revolutionary creation, which threatens to cripple their businesses, never reaches mass production. Similarly, the humble workers in the labor union, upon learning of Sidney's invention, also strive to erase it from existence, fearing for their job security. Despite facing violence and being offered ₤250,000 in compensation, Sidney remains resolute, convinced that his everlasting fabric will bring relief and happiness to many. Throughout his struggles to gain
prompts:
Generate similar texts. Your answer must be in the same format as the examples. Text: Ealing Studios, a television and film production company based in West London, claims to be the oldest film studio in the world. Though it has been consistently churning out films and television programmes since the 1930s, its golden age was most certainly between 1948 and 1955, when it produced a string of comedy masterpieces, many starring the great Alec Guinness. Such well-known titles include 'Whisky Galore! (1949),' 'Passport to Pimlico (1949),' 'Kind Hearts and Coronets (1949),' 'The Lavender Hill Mob (1951),' 'The Titfield Thunderbolt (1953)' and 'The Ladykillers (1955).' One of Ealing Studio's most beloved films, 'The Man in the White Suit,' was released in 1951, and starred Alec Guiness as Sidney Stratton, a brilliant inventor who engineers a remarkable fabric, an invention that unexpectedly makes him more enemies than friends.

Sidney Stratton is poor and unappreciated, but he has scientific talent in great abundance. Due to his under-qualification, the only jobs he is able to get are as a janitor or labourer at any of the large textile factories, where he secretly undertakes his own experiments using the company's own money and equipment. After being found out and ejected countless times, Sidney is convinced that he is only weeks away from a momentous scientific discovery that will revolutionise the textiles industry. Encouraged by his daughter Daphne (Joan Greenwood), textile mill owner Alan Birnley (Cecil Parker) takes a keen interest in Sidney's exploits and agrees to finance any further work. After numerous failed attempts and quite a few earth-shattering explosions, Sidney eventually unveils his amazing creation: an almost-luminous white fabric that never gets dirty and never wears out.

If Sidney thought that his invention would make him a hero, then he was sorely disappointed. The all-powerful bosses of textiles industry, headed by the frail Sir John Kierlaw (Ernest Thesiger), unite to ensure that the revolutionary invention, which could completely cripple their businesses, never goes into full-scale production. Likewise, the humble labourers in the workers' union hear of Sidney's creation and also set out to erase it from existence, fearing for their jobs. The inventor, however, is convinced that the ever-lasting fabric will bring relief and happiness to many, and refuses to give in to the demand of others, despite being threatened with violence and offered ₤250,000 in compensation. Throughout all his troubles to announce his invention to the media, only one person offers Sidney her complete sympathy and support, Birnley's daughter Daphne, who is engaged to be married to somebody else but falls in love with Sidney's plight anyway.

'The Man in the White Suit' is a clever and hilarious comedy, made great by a witty script (written by John Dighton, Roger MacDougall and director Alexander Mackendrick) and a quirky and charismatic performance from an inimitable Alec Guinness. There are also a few good-natured swipes at capitalism, and of how big industries can hold back progress for the sake of their own monetary situations, though we can certainly see the arguments for either side of the debate. results:
There are so many things that are incredibly wrong with this absolutely terrible little disaster of a film that it's difficult to even know where to start.

To begin with, it's an incredibly un-scary horror movie, even by American standards. The dialogue is completely cliché, the characters are completely one-dimensional, the writing is completely uninspired, and the minimal story that does exist is neither coherent nor remotely interesting.

We are introduced to the following stereotypes in rapid succession: a Balding Loser Guy (who may or may not be divorced, but the movie never bothers to tell us) with a heart of gold, a Young Hero (who never actually does anything heroic), a Brave Little Kid (with a disturbingly violent streak), and a Black Bad-Ass Woman (with more muscle than brains). These characters engage in an ongoing battle with the Tall Scary Reaper Man and his evil Ewoks.

Oh, and the film is filled with these little metal orbs that fly around and menace people. If given the opportunity, they perform impromptu brain surgery on those who aren't smart enough to dodge them. Boo! Actually, one of them is haunted by a good ghost (although it could also be a deceptive specter) who seems determined to help our Brave Protagonists rescue their kidnapped friend.

There is absolutely no background information or even an introduction given for any of the characters. The movie starts with some kind of recap of the previous film's ending, but it doesn't really explain much. If you've seen the first two movies, great. Otherwise, you have no idea who these people are, how they are connected, why they aren't in school or at work, or why you should even care if they live or die. As a result, you simply don't. The only mildly interesting aspect becomes any instances of gore. And unfortunately, there aren't enough of those to keep you awake.

The only potentially interesting or amusing part of the movie is the three Raider Punks, who are just as stupid as they are evil and who torment Our Heroes. However, they are quickly dispatched and then buried (although why anyone would bother is beyond comprehension), only to reappear as Evil Raider Punk Zombies. Yet, they are quickly dispatched again, this time within a matter of minutes.

The majority of the film seems to consist of Casper the Friendly

results:
Why is there such a morbid fascination with death in nature documentaries? It's not like we need a PhD to know that death happens all the time in the wild. But for some reason, filmmakers seem obsessed with showing us the most gruesome and violent moments. Do we really need to see a lion tearing apart an innocent elephant? Or a cheetah suffocating a gazelle in slow motion? It's supposed to be a family-friendly film, for crying out loud!

And why is it that the filmmakers are too scared to include these violent scenes in the trailers? Are they afraid it will scare away potential viewers? It's a shame that they don't have the courage to be upfront about the violent content.

But of course, they can't resist adding some comic relief to the mix. Suddenly, we're subjected to a ridiculous narration about Birds-of-Paradise and their mating rituals. It's like they think they're talking to a room full of 6-year-olds on a school trip. Talk about a drastic shift in tone!

If any aspiring nature documentary filmmakers are reading this, here's a suggestion: focus on the more positive and fascinating aspects of wildlife. Show us animals copulating, giving birth, and engaging in other natural behaviors. Highlight their social interactions, problem-solving skills, and unique cultural practices. Let's see more of the beauty and inspiration that nature has to offer, and less of the violence and mindless narration.
prompts:
Generate similar texts. Your answer must be in the same format as the examples. Text: A lot of death happens in the wild. You don't need to be a rocket scientist to figure that out! But does it need to be the focus of a nature documentary? What is with this fascination with gruesome death? Do we really have to see an adult elephant torn to shreds by a pack of hungry lions? Or, a cheetah grabbing a gazelle by the throat in slow motion, no less! I thought this was going to be a family-friendly nature film!

And, why not have the courage to show the gruesome violence in the film's trailers? Were the filmmakers afraid of losing money?

Then in typical, comic relief fashion we get to see the magnificent Birds-of-Paradise perform mating rituals to the most annoying and stupid narration humanly possible. It was surreal! It's as if the filmmakers believed they were only addressing a roomful of First and Second graders on a school field trip! Wow! From the mean to the moronic in a heartbeat!

If there are any future nature documentary filmmakers waiting in the wings reading this film review, why not focus on: Animals actually copulating; giving birth; laying eggs; bathing; sleeping; cleaning each other; socializing; playing; emotional displays other than fear and anger; unusual behaviors, like mouth brooding; migration; problem solving skills; culture (yes, many animal species have what humans call culture); communication skills; parenting, healing abilities, etc. In other words, stop focusing on violence or dumbing down beauty, and why not be much more well-rounded - and focus on delight and inspiration, instead? Text:

Let's see more of the beauty and inspiration that nature has to offer, and less of the violence and mindless narration.

results:
This pathetic excuse for a film is so riddled with flaws that it's difficult to pinpoint where to begin.

For starters, it fails miserably at being a horror movie, even by American standards. The dialogue is cliché, the characters are one-dimensional, the writing is uninspired, and the nonexistent plot is both incoherent and uninteresting.

We are introduced to a series of predictable stereotypes: a middle-aged loser with a supposed brave heart, a young hero who does nothing remotely heroic, a disturbed child with a violent streak, and a tough woman who relies on brute strength rather than intelligence. They engage in an ongoing battle with a tall, menacing figure and his evil minions.

To add to the absurdity, the film features malevolent metal orbs flying around and attacking people. If given the chance, they perform impromptu brain surgery on those unfortunate enough to be caught off guard. Boo! One of the orbs is even haunted by a supposedly good ghost, although its true intentions are questionable. This ghost is oddly focused on helping our supposed protagonists rescue their kidnapped friend.

There is no background information provided for any of the characters, nor is there an introduction to their relationships or reasons for not being at school or work. The movie begins with a confusing recap of the previous installment, which does little to clarify anything. If you haven't seen the previous movies, you'll be left in the dark about who these people are and why their lives matter. As a result, you won't care whether they live or die. The only mildly interesting aspects are the occasional gore effects, but even those are few and far between.

The only potentially entertaining element is a group of idiotic and malevolent punks who antagonize our heroes. However, they are dispatched almost immediately and then inexplicably resurrected as evil zombie versions, only to be killed off again within moments.

The majority of the film consists of a friendly ghost named Caspar appearing and disappearing, aimlessly driving around, and the middle-aged loser attempting to seduce the tough woman with cringe-worthy pickup lines that would embarrass a mentally challenged teenager. Unsurprisingly, his efforts are fruitless, and not even gratuitous sex could salvage this abysmal movie (not that there is any).

The main villain, known as the Tall Man, fails to instill fear in

This pathetic excuse for a film is so riddled with flaws that it's difficult to pinpoint where to begin.

For starters, it fails miserably at being a horror movie, even by American standards. The dialogue is cliché, the characters are one-dimensional, the writing is uninspired, and the nonexistent plot is both incoherent and uninteresting.

We are introduced to a series of predictable stereotypes: a middle-aged loser with a supposed brave heart, a young hero who does nothing remotely heroic, a disturbed child with a violent streak, and a tough woman who relies on brute strength rather than intelligence. They engage in an ongoing battle with a tall, menacing figure and his evil minions.

To add to the absurdity, the film features malevolent metal orbs flying around and attacking people. If given the chance, they perform impromptu brain surgery on those unfortunate enough to be caught off guard. Boo! One of the orbs is even haunted by a supposedly good ghost, although its true intentions are questionable. This ghost is oddly focused on helping our supposed protagonists rescue their kidnapped friend.

There is no background information provided for any of the characters, nor is there an introduction to their relationships or reasons for not being at school or work. The movie begins with a confusing recap of the previous installment, which does little to clarify anything. If you haven't seen the previous movies, you'll be left in the dark about who these people are and why their lives matter. As a result, you won't care whether they live or die. The only mildly interesting aspects are the occasional gore effects, but even those are few and far between.

The only potentially entertaining element is a group of idiotic and malevolent punks who antagonize our heroes. However, they are dispatched almost immediately and then inexplicably resurrected as evil zombie versions, only to be killed off again within moments.

The majority of the film consists of a friendly ghost named Caspar appearing and disappearing, aimlessly driving around, and the middle-aged loser attempting to seduce the tough woman with cringe-worthy pickup lines that would embarrass a mentally challenged teenager. Unsurprisingly, his efforts are fruitless, and not even gratuitous sex could salvage this abysmal movie (not that there is any).

results:
Why must death be such a prominent theme in nature documentaries? Surely, it's not necessary to showcase the brutal demise of animals in such explicit detail. The sight of a majestic elephant being torn apart by a hungry lion pack or a cheetah slowly strangling a gazelle is hardly suitable for a family-friendly film. It's disappointing that these violent scenes weren't even included in the film's trailers - were the filmmakers too afraid of losing profits?

And then, as if to lighten the mood, we're suddenly subjected to an absurdly narrated segment on the mating rituals of Birds-of-Paradise. It felt like the filmmakers were speaking to a group of young children on a school outing. The abrupt shift from gruesome to comical was jarring, to say the least!

To any aspiring nature documentary makers out there, consider focusing on the more positive aspects of animal life. Highlight their reproductive habits, birthing processes, and nurturing behaviors. Showcase their daily activities like bathing, sleeping, grooming, and socializing. Explore their emotional displays beyond fear and anger, and delve into their unique behaviors such as mouth brooding or migration. Give us a glimpse of their problem-solving abilities, communication skills, and parenting techniques. Let's move away from violence and embrace the beauty, joy, and inspiration that nature has to offer.
prompts:
Generate similar texts. Your answer must be in the same format as the examples. Text: A lot of death happens in the wild. You don't need to be a rocket scientist to figure that out! But does it need to be the focus of a nature documentary? What is with this fascination with gruesome death? Do we really have to see an adult elephant torn to shreds by a pack of hungry lions? Or, a cheetah grabbing a gazelle by the throat in slow motion, no less! I thought this was going to be a family-friendly nature film!

And, why not have the courage to show the gruesome violence in the film's trailers? Were the filmmakers afraid of losing money?

Then in typical, comic relief fashion we get to see the magnificent Birds-of-Paradise perform mating rituals to the most annoying and stupid narration humanly possible. It was surreal! It's as if the filmmakers believed they were only addressing a roomful of First and Second graders on a school field trip! Wow! From the mean to the moronic in a heartbeat!

If there are any future nature documentary filmmakers waiting in the wings reading this film review, why not focus on: Animals actually copulating; giving birth; laying eggs; bathing; sleeping; cleaning each other; socializing; playing; emotional displays other than fear and anger; unusual behaviors, like mouth brooding; migration; problem solving skills; culture (yes, many animal species have what humans call culture); communication skills; parenting, healing abilities, etc. In other words, stop focusing on violence or dumbing down beauty, and why not be much more well-rounded - and focus on delight and inspiration, instead? results:
Why is there such an obsession with death in nature documentaries? It seems like every film wants to showcase the most gruesome and violent moments. Is it really necessary to show an innocent elephant being torn apart by lions? Or a cheetah strangling a gazelle in slow motion? This is not the family-friendly content I was expecting! And why are these brutal scenes never included in the trailers? Are the filmmakers afraid of scaring away viewers and losing money? It's disappointing that they don't have the courage to be upfront about the violence.

On the other hand, we are subjected to ridiculous and irritating narration when watching the beautiful Birds-of-Paradise perform their mating rituals. It's as if the filmmakers believe their audience consists solely of young children on a field trip. It's a jarring shift from the gruesome to the mindless in an instant!

For any aspiring nature documentary directors reading this review, I have a suggestion: why not focus on the more positive and fascinating aspects of animal behavior? There are so many incredible moments to capture, such as animals mating, giving birth, bathing, sleeping, and socializing. We could also explore their problem-solving skills, communication abilities, and unique cultural practices. Instead of fixating on violence, let's showcase the beauty, inspiration, and diversity of the natural world.

results:
There are so many flaws with this terrible excuse for a movie that it's difficult to even know where to start. To begin with, it's an incredibly unconvincing horror film, even by American standards. The dialogue is cliché, the characters are one-dimensional, the writing is mediocre, and the minimal plot is neither cohesive nor remotely engaging.

We are introduced to the following stereotypes in sequence: a balding loser guy (potentially divorced, but the movie fails to clarify), a young hero who isn't remotely heroic, a brave little kid with a disturbingly violent streak, and a black bad-ass woman with more brawn than brains. These individuals find themselves in an ongoing battle against the tall, menacing reaper man and his evil Ewoks.

Oh, and there are these small, malevolent metal orbs that fly around menacingly, occasionally performing impromptu brain surgery on those who lack the mental capacity to avoid them. Boo! Actually, one of these orbs is haunted by a benevolent ghost (or perhaps a deceitful specter) who appears to be determined to help our brave protagonists rescue their kidnapped friend.

None of the characters have any background or even an introduction. The movie begins with some sort of recap of the previous film's ending, but this doesn't provide much explanation. If you've seen the first two movies, great. Otherwise, you have no idea who these people are, how they are connected, why they aren't in school or at work, or why you should care whether they live or die. Consequently, you simply don't care. The only remotely interesting aspect becomes the occasional gory scene, but even those are few and far between.

The only potentially amusing aspect is the trio of raider punks, as idiotic as they are evil, who pose a threat to our heroes. However, they are disposed of almost immediately. Then, inexplicably, they are buried (why anyone would bother is beyond me), only to return as evil raider punk zombies. Yet they are once again quickly eliminated, literally within a minute.

The majority of the film seems to consist of Casper the Friendly Ghost appearing and disappearing, driving around aimlessly, and the balding loser attempting to seduce the black bad-ass woman with pickup lines that would embarrass a mentally challenged teenager. No luck there; not even some gratuitous sex could have salvaged this film, so it's probably for the best that it never occurs.

The main

First of all, it's a remarkably un-scary scary movie, even by Amercian standards. The dialogue is cliché, the characters are two-dimensional, the writing is ho-hum, and what little story there is is neither coherent nor remotely interesting.

We meet the following stereotypes in order: Balding Loser Guy (probably divorced, but who knows? This movie doesn't tell us) with a brave heart, the Young Hero (who doesn't do anything heroic at all), Brave Little Kid (with a homicidal streak a mile wide) and Black Bad-Ass Bitch (with more brawn than brains). These guys take up an ongoing fight with the Tall Scary Reaper Man and his evil Ewoks.

Oh, and the film is full of wicked little metal orbs whoosing around menacing people. Given a chance, they perform impromptu brain surgery on those who doen't have the mental acuity to duck when they come at them. Booh! Actually, one of them is haunted by a good ghost (but then again, it might be a deceitful spectre) who seems intent on helping our Brave Contagonists retrieve their young kidnapped friend.

There is no character background or even an introduction to any of the characters. It starts with some kind of recap of the ending of the previous movie, but this doesn't explain a lot. If you've seen the first two movies, fine. Otherwise you don't know who these people are, how they are related, why they aren't in school or at work, or why you should care whether they live or die. Consequently, you don't. The only point of interest becomes any splatter effects. And there aren't enough of those to keep you awake.

Of potenial interest/amusement are the three Raider Punks, as stupid as they are evil, who menace Our Heroes. But they don't get much screen time. They are offed almost immediately. Then they are buried (why anybody should take the time is beyond me), then they appear again as Evil Raider Punk Zombies. Only to be offed again, literally within a minute.

The rest of the movie mainly seems to consist of Caspar the Friendly Ghost appearing and disappearing, driving around looking for places, and Balding Loser trying to score som Bad Black Bitch Booty, using pickup lines that would embarrass a mentally retarded teenager. No dice there; not even some gratuitous sex could have saved this movie, so good thing there never is any.

The head baddie, called the Tall Man, doesn't manage to scare anyone older than 3 years; howling 'Booooy!' every five minutes isn't enough. Why he, with his amazing telekinetic powers and uncanny upper-body strength, doesn't simply squash our heroes like bugs isn't explained. Instead, he delegates the job to his inept retarded little minions, who never manage to kill anyone before being shot to hell.
